title: Private equity (and the press) dine on supermarket deals
text:
One thing to start: the $24bn deal for Lucid Motors to go public was unable to close on Thursday, after the blank-cheque company merging with the electric vehicle start-up failed to put together enough support from retail investors at a crucial shareholder meeting. Full story here.

The private equity trend being devoured by UK newspapers

DD wants to let you in on a little secret about the British press. 

Nothing gets pulses racing at UK newspapers like a takeover battle involving one of the country's main grocery chains. 

Sure, the powerful and dominant technology companies in the modern economy are based far beyond the shores of the UK. 

But that doesn't stop the unrivalled attention and media column inches spent here whenever the likes of Tesco, J Sainsbury or one of their main rivals is the subject of a potential acquisition.

So, while supermarkets fretted over keeping shelves stocked and customers satisfied during the pandemic, the past 12 months have actually been great for business news coverage on the subject.

First, an investor group consisting of the billionaire Issa brothers and buyout group TDR Capital defeated Apollo Global Management to take over UK grocer Asda from Walmart in a £6.8bn deal. 

And now, we have the prospect of a bidding war for Wm Morrison, the fourth-largest grocery chain in the UK and the smaller rival to Asda.

An investor group led by SoftBank-owned Fortress Investment Group has agreed to buy Morrisons for £9.5bn including debt. On Thursday, Morrisons released the fine print on the offer ahead of a shareholder vote on August 16 to ink the deal. 

The paperwork included a favourite for DD readers — the fees associated with the deal, which surpass £300m altogether. 

They appear to handsomely reward Rothschild as lead adviser to Morrisons, along with HSBC and RBC Capital Markets, who are advising and helping finance the consortium.

On Thursday, we also learnt that the UK's Takeover Panel has set an August 9 deadline for US private equity firm Clayton, Dubilier & Rice to bid after it already had one approach rejected.

DD is expecting CD&R, which is working with Goldman Sachs, to return with an improved offer. 

Returning to the theme at the start of the newsletter, all of this attention has been a bit disorientating for private equity groups doing business in the UK. 

They feel as though they're having a unique moment of attention from media outlets, such as The Daily Mail tabloid, who have hitherto ignored their existence. Now, all of sudden these publications are paying more attention and publishing detailed manifestos on how to reform the industry. 

It's almost as though the private equity firms weren't aware of what would happen if they started bidding for the UK media's favourite sector. 

The healthcare tycoon alleging he's the victim of a ‘debt-fuelled Ponzi scheme'

A new front has opened in the international legal battle over the collapse of NMC Health. 

BR Shetty, founder of the hospital and fertility clinic company, has filed an $8bn lawsuit accusing its fired chief executive, its auditor EY, and two banks of conspiring in a six-year fraud.

A quick recap: NMC is the company the Indian tycoon created in Abu Dhabi in 1975 and listed in London in 2012, where it joined the FTSE 100 index in 2017. 

The company filed for administration in April last year after the discovery of more than $4bn of undisclosed company debt following allegations by US short seller Muddy Waters that NMC had reported profit margins that were “too good to be true”. 

The case, filed by Shetty in New York last week, alleges he was defrauded through a “debt-fuelled Ponzi scheme”, according to this report by the FT's Michael O'Dwyer and Cynthia O'Murchu.

NMC's ousted chief executive Prasanth Manghat and his brother Promoth, who led Shetty's fintech company Finablr until last year, are accused of conspiring over the circular movement of funds between NMC and related companies to artificially inflate sales figures.

These figures were used to obtain off-balance-sheet loans that were siphoned off by the alleged fraudsters and used to pay kickbacks to co-conspirators, Shetty's lawyers claimed. The Manghats have both previously denied wrongdoing.

EY, which is already facing a possible professional negligence claim from administrators Alvarez & Marsal, is accused of helping to conceal the alleged fraud by advising NMC on how it could use “illicit tactics” to inflate its earnings and to avoid loans appearing in the financial statements.

EY said the case was “without merit” and that it would defend itself vigorously. 

Shetty also alleged that the scheme would never have got off the ground if Bank of Baroda, one of India's biggest lenders, had carried out basic anti-money laundering checks on suspicious transactions and that Netherlands-based Credit Europe Bank turned a blind eye to “bogus” invoices so it could keep earning fees. 

Shetty, who previously made similar claims of being defrauded following an investigation he commissioned last year, faces legal problems of his own over NMC's demise. 

He has been hit with multiple freezing orders and was the subject of a criminal complaint in the UAE last year. 

Wall Street bankers redirect Chinese clients' New York listings

An impatient queue of Chinese tech start-ups waiting to list in New York are rerouting their plans to neighbouring Hong Kong, as their investment bankers scramble to circumvent Beijing's increasingly tough regulation on Wall Street IPOs.

Earlier this month we told you about Didi, the ride-hailing group lauded as China's answer to Uber, caught in the crossfire of its government's regulatory crackdown on US flotations.

Didi highlighted how data security issues are at the centre of China's crackdown on foreign listings. Shortly after it floated in New York, Beijing launched an investigation into the company, sending the shares down 20 per cent from the IPO price. 

It also prompted top officials in Beijing to call for a new regulatory regime to police overseas IPOs while the Cyberspace Administration of China proposed rules banning companies with more than 1m users from listing abroad without a security review and official permission. 

As a result, companies with large data components to their business are looking to switch planned listings to Hong Kong. 

“We're speaking to everyone about it. All the Chinese issuers planning New York IPOs are looking at whether they can pivot to Hong Kong,” a senior capital markets banker in Hong Kong told the FT.

The pivot comes as Chinese companies raised a record $12.4bn on the New York Stock Exchange in the first half of this year — a lucrative arrangement for US banks that raked in fee revenues even as US-China relations worsened.

One reason dealmakers may not be thrilled about the flow of Chinese listings going from New York to Hong Kong is down to fees. Bankers receive average fees of 2 per cent from an IPO in the region, compared to 5-7 per cent in the US.

Job moves

  • GlaxoSmithKline has appointed Brian McNamara to lead its consumer health division after next year's spin-off. He joined the UK drugmaker in 2015 from Novartis and has led the consumer unit since its previous head Emma Walmsley was promoted to chief executive. 

  • After more than 20 years as chief executive of London-listed insurer Hiscox, Bronek Masojada is stepping down. He will be replaced by Hiscox's chief financial officer Aki Hussain. 

  • Barclays has hired Ingrid Hengster as country chief executive for Germany and as a global chair of investment banking. She joins from KfW Bankengruppe, where she was an executive board member.

  • JPMorgan Chase has rehired Louise Bennetts as head of Emea director advisory services. She has previously worked at law firm Davis Polk & Wardwell. 

  • Credit Suisse has lost yet another banker — the head of west coast internet investment banking Homan Milani has resigned. He will be joining Bank of America, per Bloomberg.
